newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore HSFO rangebound, looks to crude for lead.
newsitem.headline: Singapore HSFO rangebound, looks to crude for lead.

text.p: High sulphur fuel oil prices on Friday remained directionless and were expected to be stuck in a range with most players looking to the crude market for a lead, traders said.
Bid/asked for cash 180 cst supplies for October loading were likely to hover between $115 and $117 a tonne--similiar to Thursday's levels, they said.
"At this price, people are cautious to take length," one major said.
Players are looking to sell to China where bids were seen around $128 per tonne, cost-and-freight basis, one trader said.
Sources report the recent sale of an 80,000-tonne 380 cst cargo from Kuwait for loading in mid-October at about $2.10 premium to Singapore spot quotes, on a c-and-f basis.
They said another 80,000-tonne cargo would be shipped in October from Kuwait to Singapore.

Despite the rise in imports some traders remained bullish on lower stocks in Singapore which for the week ending September 25 stood at 9.737 million barrels--below the typical 10-11 million barrels earlier this year, according Singapore's Trade Development Board data.
October paper, was bid/asked at $115.50/116.50, slightly firmer than Thursday's quotes at $115.25/$116.25.
